type.title: Common
type.explanation: These are everyday names for just about any situation.  Some sound more impressive than others, but they all come across as ordinary names that anyone could bear.  Because of the vast number of combinations possible with names, these are by no means intended to represent the “most” common names.

romanisation.meaning: Guoqing: National Day holiday in China
Aimin: Care for the common people (usually said of a ruler, official, army, etc.)
Lei: Heap of stones, open and honest

type.title: Uncommon
type.explanation: These names feature uncommon or archaic characters that aren’t often seen.  Generally speaking, these names sound impressive and unique, and are the type that would stand out or be easy to recall.

romanisation.meaning: Changqing: An archaic word for butterfly
Zi: Child, son, first Earthly branch

type.title: Dark
type.explanation: These are names that generally come across as either sounding evil, dangerous, violent, or negative in some way.  Generally, they are perfect for villainous characters, or at least, characters who are not righteous heroes.  They are best paired with the Dark surnames above, although that is not a hard and fast rule.

romanisation.meaning: Chou: Enemy, foe, hate, loathe, grudge
Shang: Die in war, die young
Sha: Brake, stop (This character is pronounced the same and resembles the character for “kill” 殺/杀)
Mochou: This is the given name of a famous wuxia villainess, Li Mouchou
Mo: Do not, there is none who
Yue: Amputate the feet as punishment
Ling: The sound of flowing water

type.title: Righteous
type.explanation: These are names that sound upright, righteous, and good.  They are the type of names you would expect to be borne by heroic people who espouse justice and fight for the commoners.

romanisation.meaning: Peng: The Peng, a mythological bird sometimes translated as “roc”
Wei: Did not, have not, eighth Earthly branch

type.title: Dramatic
type.explanation: These are names which sound emotional, melancholic, or dramatic in some way.  They are best paired with the Dramatic surnames above, although that is not a hard and fast rule.

romanisation.meaning: Zhuang: To dress up, to adorn, makeup
Zhen: Pillow, rest one’s head in sleep
Changqing: A rare word for butterfly
Zi: Child, son, first Earthly branch
Xi: No meaning, this character is an exclamatory particle

type.title: Masculine
type.explanation: These names all sound masculine in nature.

romanisation.meaning: Qiankun: Heaven and earth, Yin and Yang, the universe, the cosmos
Qian: Heaven, male, Yang-related, one of the eight trigrams
Kun: Earth, feminine, female, Yin-related, one of the eight trigrams

type.title: Feminine
type.explanation: These names all sound feminine in nature.

romanisation.meaning: Ziwei: Crape myrtle (a tree that usually has purplish flowers)

type.title: Gender-Neutral
type.explanation: These are names which are not immediately identifiable as being either masculine or feminine.

romanisation.meaning: Qiming: Classical Chinese name for planet Venus
Chen: Celestial bodies, fifth Earthly branch
Zi: Child, son, first Earthly branch

type.title: Artisan
type.explanation: For the most part, these are just ordinary names that you would expect a common person to have.  Being prepared for Artisans in mind, many have a fanciful, creative feeling to them.

romanisation.meaning: Yang: Positive, sun, hot, masculine (from Yin and Yang)
Chen: Celestial bodies, fifth Earthly branch

type.title: Assassin
type.explanation: These names are perfect for hardened killers.  Most sound dramatic or dangerous.

romanisation.meaning: Jing: Chaste tree (a type of tree), thorns, brambles
Yao: Want, ask for, demand, request
Wuxin: Without thought, the mind free from illusion, mindless
Luocha: Raksha, rakshasa (demons that devour men)
Sha: Brake, stop (When used alone, this character is pronounced the same and resembles the character for “kill” 殺/杀)

type.title: Bandit
type.explanation: Most of these names sound like they would belong to common, rough-and-tumble individuals who have fallen into a life of crime.

type.title: Beggar
type.explanation: Most of these names are humble and perhaps even somewhat shameful.

romanisation.meaning: Sheng: Remain, be left, have as a remainder
Zi: Child, son, first Earthly branch
